raw_text:
Google to scan famous libraries
 
 The libraries of five of the world's most important academic institutions are to be digitised by Google.
 
 Scanned pages from books in the public domain will then be made available for search and reading online. The full libraries of Michigan and Stanford universities, as well as archives at Harvard, Oxford and the New York Public Library are included. Online pages from scanned books will not have adverts but will have links to online store Amazon, Google said.
 
 "The goal of the project is to unlock the wealth of information that is offline and bring it online," said Susan Wojcicki, director of product management at Google.
 
 There will also be links to public libraries so that the books can be borrowed. Google will not be paid for providing for the links. It will take six years to digitise the full collection at Michigan, which contains seven million volumes. Users will only have access to extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works. The New York library is allowing Google to include a small portion of books no longer covered by copyright.
 
 Harvard is limiting its participation to 40,000 books, while Oxford wants Google to scan books originally published in the 19th Century and held in the Bodleian Library. A spokeswoman for Oxford University said the digitised books would include novels, poetry, political tracts and art books. "Important works that are out of print or only available in a few libraries around the world will be made available to everyone," she said. About one million books will be scanned by Google, less than 15% of the total collection held in the Bodleian. "We hope that Oxford's contribution to this project will be of scholarly use, as well as general interest, to people around the world," said Reg Carr, director of Oxford University Library Services.
 
 "It's a significant opportunity to bring our material to the rest of the world," said Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library. "It could solve an old problem: If people can't get to us, how can we get to them?" "This is the day the world changes," said John Wilkin, a University of Michigan librarian working with Google. "It will be disruptive because some people will worry that this is the beginning of the end of libraries. "But this is something we have to do to revitalise the profession and make it more meaningful."
llama3.2:1b: Google will digitize the full collections of five major academic institutions, including Michigan University, Stanford University, Harvard University's Bodleian Library, Oxford University, and the New York Public Library, using scanned pages from public domain books.
The goal is to unlock offline information for online access, with links provided through Amazon or Google.
llama3.2:3b: Google to digitize libraries of five academic institutions, including Harvard, Oxford, Stanford, Michigan, and New York Public Library, with scanned pages made available for search and reading online, containing public domain books and extracts from copyrighted works.
gemma2:2b: Google will digitize the full collections of five prestigious universities, including Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library.
These digitized books will be available online for reading and searching, with links to Amazon and public library systems.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Google plans to digitize five world-class academic libraries, providing access to millions of books scanned from public domain sources for online search and reading.
The projects will include a subset of 40, 000 books and Oxford University's long-term collection from the 19th century held in the Bodleian Library.
Google aims to make these resources accessible to the global community through Amazon links.
This initiative is seen as crucial for breaking down barriers between libraries and making educational materials more widely available.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Google plans to digitize five major academic institutions' public domain library collections, making them searchable online with limited access to copyrighted works.
Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library's full libraries and archives will be included in the project over six years.
Books published before 1923 can be accessed through Oxford for a portion of their holdings, while Google aims to digitize approximately one million books.
The initiative is expected to open up access to information not currently available online.
qwen2.5:3b: Google plans to digitize books from five major academic institutions, including Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and New York Public Library, with content available for search and online reading.
Books in the public domain will be made accessible but copyrighted works' full texts won't be visible; users can only access extracts and bibliographies.
Google will not profit from this initiative.
The project aims to make information that is offline accessible online.

Harvard limits participation to 40,000 books, Oxford scans original publications in the 19th century for digitization, and the New York Public Library allows inclusion of copyrighted material older than their copyright.
Yale's contribution includes novels, poetry, political tracts, and art books, with about a million books scanned by Google from its total collection of around one million.
John Wilkin at University of Michigan sees this as disruptive but necessary for library revitalization.
opencoder:1.5b: Google is planning to digitize the libraries at universities like Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and New York Public Library.
The project aims to bring offline information online.
The goal of the project is to unlock a wealth of information that is held in public libraries for searching and reading.
Books from these collections can be borrowed without payment; users will only have access to extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works.
Some books that are not covered by copyright include novels, poetry, political tracts, art books, etc., which will be made available to everyone around the world.
The digitised books will include less than 15% of the total collection held in Bodleian, contributing more to Oxford's contribution.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details, including:

1.
The main idea: Google will scan famous libraries to digitize books in the public domain.
Key players involved: Google, Michigan University, Stanford University, Harvard University, and New York Public Library.
Description of the project: Google will scan books from five of the world's most important academic institutions and make them available online for search and reading.
The full libraries of these institutions are included in the project.
Excerpts or bibliographies: Users will only have access to extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works, not the entire book.
Timeline: There will be six years to digitise the full collection at Michigan University, which contains seven million volumes.
Users will only have access to extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works, not the entire book.
Details about the project: The goal is to unlock the wealth of information that is offline and bring it online, making it available to everyone.
Google will not be paid for providing links to online store Amazon.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Google plans to digitize books from five major academic institutions' libraries by scanning them online.
The Michigan collection will have seven million volumes scanned, allowing users access to extracts and bibliographies.
The New York Public Library allows Google to scan a small portion of older books.

This initiative aims to bring offline information to the public, benefiting libraries like Harvard and Oxford which limit participation to 40,000 books and include specific types of works respectively.
The goal is to unlock library resources online and provide digitized content to a broader audience.
tinyllama:1.1b: Google has announced that it has scanned various academic libraries, including Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Librarity, into its Google Books project.
The project will digitize book pages from books in the public domain, making them available for online search and reading.
Users will only be able to access extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works, while Harvard has limited its participation to 40,000 books.
This project is aimed at unlocking the wealth of information that's offline and bringing it online, while also providing a means of supporting academic research.
The digitization of books will be made available for general public interest as well as scholarly use.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Google project to digitize five of the world's most important academic institutions’ libraries aims at unlocking the wealth of information that is offline and making them available online.
They will scan the full collections of Michigan, Stanford, Oxford and the New York Public Library.
Users can access extracts from books with links to online stores like Amazon and read articles or see images from scanned pages without any adverts.
This project is expected to take six years to complete.
The goal is to make this information available to everyone around the world.
phi:2.7b: Google plans to digitize five major academic institutions' libraries, making their public domain books available online for reading and search.
While Google will not be paid for providing links to these online stores, they will provide full access to scanned pages from the books.
The project aims to unlock the wealth of information that is offline and make it available to everyone.
However, only a small portion of the books will have copyright restrictions in place.
orca-mini:3b: Google will scan five of the world's most important academic institutions, including Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library, for online search and reading.
The digitized pages from books in the public domain will be made available for anyone to access without advertisements.
However, copyrighted works will only have links to online stores like Amazon.
Libraries such as Harvard will limit their participation to 40,000 books, while Oxford wants Google to scan books originally published in the 19th Century and held in the Bodleian Library.
The project aims to bring offline information online.
hermes3:3b: Google to scan 1m books from 5 major academic libraries, including public domain & limited copyrighted works.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Google is partnering with five major academic institutions - Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and New York Public Library - to digitize their library collections.
The initiative aims to bring offline information online by allowing search and reading of scanned public domain books on Google's platform without ads but with links to Amazon.
Users will have access to extract and bibliography portions of copyrighted works.
The project is set to take six years and involves seven million volumes at Michigan, 40,000 books at Harvard, and about one million books at Oxford.
The New York Public Library hopes the initiative will solve the problem of reaching patrons who can't visit in person, while some fear it may disrupt the library profession entirely.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Google is digitizing the libraries of five major academic institutions—Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library—to make public domain books searchable and readable online.
Michigan's full collection of seven million volumes will take six years to scan, while Harvard is limiting participation to 40,000 books, and Oxford is focusing on 19th-century works.
Users will access extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted books, and links to public libraries will allow borrowing.
The project aims to make rare and out-of-print works widely accessible.
Google will not include ads but will provide links to Amazon.
Library officials see this as a transformative step in expanding global access to knowledge.
stablelm2:1.6b: Google will digitize libraries from five important academic institutions, including Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library, with scanned pages from public domain books available for online search and reading.
Books will not have ads but may include links to Amazon.
Google is taking six years to complete the project; less than 1% of the total collection held in the Bodleian Library.
About one million books will be scanned, with links to libraries for borrowing.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Google has initiated a six-year project to digitize books from five prestigious institutions: Michigan, Stanford, Harvard, Oxford, and the New York Public Library.
This initiative aims to convert public domain pages into online resources for search and reading.
Google will not charge for these services.

The full collections will take varying time to digitize: six years for Michigan's seven million volumes, while smaller portions of Harvard (40,000 books), Oxford (19th-century Bodleian Library books), and a portion of New York's collection are being included.
Only extracts and bibliographies of copyrighted works will be accessible online, with no advertisements.
Users can borrow physical copies from public libraries if they find digitized content valuable.
Oxford plans to contribute 15% of the Bodleian Library's collection, focusing on 19th-century novels, poetry, political tracts, and art books.
Google and participating institutions view this project as a way to expand access to valuable literature worldwide, enhancing scholarly research and general interest.
The Michigan librarian noted that while the project is disruptive, it represents an opportunity to revitalize libraries by making them more meaningful to users.
